Unnamed: 1: Executive management (Bands A, B and C)

1. The Telstra Group (Telstra) refers to Telstra Group and its owned and controlled entities. This includes, but is not limited to, Telstra Limited, Telstra InfraCo, Amplitel and Telstra International. Information regarding the controlled entities in the Telstra Group can be found on our website at telstra.com.au/aboutus/investors/financial-information/financial-results.

2. Direct headcount includes all permanent, fixed term, casual, contract and agency labour employees in the Telstra Group and its owned and controlled entities included within our Telstra Group HR System. Diversity data may not be available for some controlled entities due to incomplete records. There are several controlled entities that are not captured within our Telstra Group HR System and so are not included in our direct headcount (e.g. Digicel Pacific, Fetch TV and Pacific Business Solutions). This equates to 6.9% of our direct headcount. Work is underway to include these entities in future disclosures.
3. Indirect headcount includes labour under the direction of outsourced partners who have access to Telstra systems in order to deliver services (e.g. consultants).
4. Direct full time equivalent (FTE) includes employees (permanent, fixed term, casual and long term leave); contract and agency labour; and controlled entity labour.
1. Data refers to Telstra Direct headcount as defined above.

2. We define significant geographic locations as those with more than 100 employees. Countries with over 100 employees - Australia, Hong Kong, India, Philippines, Singapore, United Kingdom, United States of America

3. We define Contingent Workers as the contract and agency labour employees in Telstra Group and its controlled entities within the Telstra Group HR System that are included in our Direct workforce definition.
4. Other countries are Canada, China, France, Germany, Indonesia, Japan, Republic of Korea, Malaysia, Netherlands, New Zealand, South Africa, Sweden, Taiwan, Thailand and Uanited Arab Emirites.
Telstra Group global labour risk profile1,2
1. Data refers to Telstra Group Direct and Indirect headcount exposure to labour risk by location (with more than 100 employees).

2. Labour rights risks were calculated based on countries’ scores in three relevant global indices: the Freedom House Global Freedom Score; the Global Slavery Index’s analysis of countries’ vulnerability to modern slavery; and the World Bank’s Worldwide Governance Indicators.

1. Data refers to Telstra Direct headcount as defined above.
2. Turnover is the number of employees who leave Telstra including all types of separation, based on HR data.
3. Voluntary Separation includes Resignation, Resigned during Performance Management Process, Health Reasons, Personal Reasons, Job Abandonment.
4. Involuntary Separation includes End of Fixed Term Contract, Dismissal, Redundancy.
5. Rate (%) refers to the proportion of new hires to total Direct Headcount.

1. Data refers to Telstra Direct headcount as defined above who returned to work after parental leave ended within the reporting period. This includes Australian employees only, as per our parental leave policy.
2. Rate calculated as Total number of employees that did return to work after parental leave/ Total number of employees due to return to work after taking parental leave x 100.
3. Return to work defined as separation date being at least 3 days post last day of parental leave. Includes employee initiated separations.
4. Some of our workforce have selected to not self-disclose their gender, meaning that gender records may not be truly reflective of the diversity of our workforce.

Executive management 3
(Bands A, B and C)
1. Data refers to FY23 Telstra Group Direct headcount as defined above.
2. Number and percentage relates to non-executive Directors of Telstra Group Limited.
3. Executive management comprises persons holding roles within Telstra designated as Bands A, B and C. CEO is also included in the executive management total.
4. Middle management comprises persons holding roles within Telstra designated as Bands 1 or 2, or equivalent.
5. Operational comprises persons holding roles within Telstra designated as Bands 3 or 4, or equivalent.
6. In FY23, there are 280 employees that do not have band available due to the controlled entity type construct.

4. Middle management comprises persons holding roles within Telstra designated as Bands 1 or 2, or equivalent.
5. Operational comprises persons holding roles within Telstra designated as Bands 3 or 4, or equivalent.
6. In FY23, there are 280 employees that do not have band available due to the controlled entity type construct.

Telstra workplace health and safety indicators1
1 - Data refers to FY23 Telstra Group Direct headcount as defined above.
2 - From FY20, only claims with activity within the most recent one month are counted as 'open'. Previously claims with activity within the most recent four months were counted as 'open'.
3 - We have restated data from previous years to report on new acceptable workers' comepnsation claims only.
Telstra Total Recordable Injury Frequency Rate1
1 - Data refers to FY23 Telstra Group Direct headcount as defined above.
2 - In 2019, we updated how we calculate our TRIFR to include mental health incidents and remove claims that were rejected.
3 - TRIFR refers to the rate of occurrence of all injuries requiring intervention beyond simple first aid.
4 - We have restated data from FY22 to account for increase in TRIFR due to escalation in injury severity post initial report.
Telstra Lost Time Injury Performance Indicators1,2,3
1 - Data refers to FY23 Telstra Group Direct headcount as defined above.
2 - LTIFR is the reported number per million hours worked of all work-related injuries or diseases that result in one or more days of lost time (for Australian-based Telstra employees).
3 - This metric is no longer dependent on having a worker’s compensation claim.
4 - We have restated data from FY22 to account for increase in LTIFR due to escalation in injury severity post initial report.
Total % resulting in a high severity outcome
1. Data refers to Telstra Direct Workforce as defined above.
2. High severity injuries are work related incidents resulting in medical treatment, modified duties or one or more days of lost time.
